paper_title: Construction of In<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@NH<sub>2</sub>-MIL-68(In)@In<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> Sandwich Homologous Heterojunction for Efficient CO<sub>2</sub> Photoreduction

catalyst.llm generation: In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In) In 2 S 3 (denoted as SMS(In))
catalyst.source: Herein, we construct an In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In) In 2 S 3 (denoted as SMS(In)) sandwich homologous heterojunction via a controllable in situ metal-organic frameworks (MOF) sulfuration process.
catalyst.context: Photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 into fuel and value-added chemicals as a promising method has been applied recently to ease energy-or environment-related crises.Herein, we construct an In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In) In 2 S 3 (denoted as SMS(In)) sandwich homologous heterojunction via a controllable in situ metal-organic frameworks (MOF) sulfuration process.The improved photoreduction activity mainly lies in the effective charge transfer and separation through a homogeneous interface, enhanced CO 2 adsorption and mass transfer, and plentiful reactive sites.Benefiting from this unique hollow homologous heterojunction, SMS(In)-7 obtains a CO generation rate as high as 11.23 mol g -1 h -1 with visible-light irradiation, nearly 3 times enhancement over that of pure MOF-derived In 2 S 3 .This work provides a novel insight into the utilization of MOF-based platform for an efficient atomically heterojunction design.

catalyst.context: 3.1.Characterization of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In).The successful synthesis of a uniform NH 2 -MIL-68 hexagonal prism was first evidenced by PXRD results. 35Subsequently, the SMS(In)-X converted from the as-obtained NH 2 -MIL-68(In) through a liquid phase sulfuration reaction in a certain period of time was studied with PXRD spectra.Four obvious diffraction peaks at 21.0, 27.6, 32.7, and 48.2could be observed in both In 2 S 3 and the composites, which were assigned to the (211), (311), (400), and (440) planes of -In 2 S 3 , respectively (Figure 1a). 36,37The NH 2 -MIL-68(In) precursor remained present in the compositions and became completely invisible until the sulfuration time reached 24 h (Figure 1a).Furthermore, the gradual sulfuration process was also proved by FTIR spectroscopy (Figure 1b).The peaks at 3490 and 3367 cm -1 indicated the symmetric and asymmetric stretching of primary amines (-NH 2 ), respectively, while the band at 1256 cm -1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of N-C. 35Figure 1b demonstrates that all of the characteristic peaks from NH 2 -MIL-68(In) became weak with increasing sulfuration time.Similar to that in the XRD spectra, they almost disappeared after 24 h of sulfuration, suggesting the complete transformation of the MOF framework to hollow In 2 S 3 . SEM was used to obtain the morphology of the materials during the sulfuration process (Figure S1).The NH 2 -MIL-68(In) hexagonal prisms obtained here afforded an average length of 9-10 m and a diameter of 660 nm.Notably, the well-preserved overall 1D hollow nanotube structure of the obtained materials was formed after the sulfuration reactions.The sandwich-like hierarchical tubular structure was further identified by TEM images (Figure 1d-g).2D In 2 S 3 nanosheets in situ grew on the inner and outer surfaces of the hollow nanotube.The thickness of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) decreased with increasing sulfuration time, from 166 nm at 7 h to 63 nm at 12 h (Figure 1e,f).Prolonging the sulfuration duration to 24 h, the NH 2 -MIL-68(In) internal wall in a sandwich was completely disappeared and pure In 2 S 3 hollow nanotube was formed (Figure 1g).This result was consistent with the PXRD and FTIR analysis. To further identify the construction of the sandwich structure of the SMS(In) heterojunction composition, the selective areas of the inner and outer surfaces of SMS(In) were examined by HRTEM imaging (Figure 1h,i).Three sets of lattice fringes with spacings of 0.311, 0.324, and 0.247 nm were obvious, which were ascribed to the (222), (311), and (331) planes of In 2 S 3 , respectively. 38By contrast, no clear lattice fringes assigned to NH 2 -MIL-68(In) appeared, which may be ascribed to the low crystallinity after sulfuration (Figure 1i). 39he lattice fringes ascribed to In 2 S 3 were distributed in the areas on the right in Figure 1h,i, corresponding to the inner and outer surfaces of hollow tubes, respectively.While the indistinguishable lattice fringes in the areas on the left in Figure 1h,i were assigned to NH 2 -MIL-68(In) components next to the inner and outer surfaces of the hollow tubes in SMS(In), respectively.All of the above results and the distinct interfaces between NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and In 2 S 3 present in Figure 1h,i indicate the successful formation of an In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In)In 2 S 3 sandwich heterogeneous structure.Elemental X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were applied to study the interaction between In 2 S 3 and NH 2 -MIL-68(In) (Figure S6).The S 2p high-resolution XPS spectrum showed two peaks at 162.7 and 161.5 eV, assigned to the S 2p 1/2 and S 2p 3/2 orbitals of divalent sulfide ions (S 2-) in SMS(In), respectively.They exhibited a positive shift of 0.2 eV compared with In 2 S 3 , which was the signal of electron migration.For O 1s, the peaks at 531.9 and 530.2 eV were attributed to the In-O bondings and O defect in NH 2 -MIL-68(In).After sulfuration, the peak of In-O bondings slightly down-shifted to 531.8 by 0.1 eV, indicating the increase of electron cloud density around O in SMS(In).The above results proved the formation of In 2 S 3 /NH 2 -MIL-68(In)/In 2 S 3 heterojunction and certain chemical interaction between In 2 S 3 and NH 2 -MIL-68(In). 33V-vis DRS analysis showed the adsorption band edges of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) at 325 for In-O clusters and 450 nm for -NH 2 functional group, respectively. 40With the partial sulfuration, the SMS(In) composites revealed an obviously enhanced absorption in the visible-light region, even extending to 600 nm.The additional absorption in the visible range was attributed to the formation of In 2 S 3 (Figure 1c).According to the Tauc plots, 41,42 the band gap energies of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 were calculated as 2.28 and 1.65 eV, respectively (as the inset of Figure 1c).2 (bpy 2,2-bipyridine) as a cocatalyst and TEOA as a hole scavenger, respectively.As shown in Figure 2a, NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 (pure In 2 S 3 ) exhibited moderate CO 2 reduction activity, with CO generation rate of 6.22 and 4.73 mol g -1 h -1 , respectively.However, SMS(In)-X (X 2 7, 12) displayed substantially improved CO 2 -to-CO conversion activities, probably benefiting from the formation of the heterogeneous structure.Strikingly, the sample of SMS(In)-7 had the highest CO production rate (11.23 mol g -1 h -1 ), even superior to the sum of the activity of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) (6.22 mol g -1 h -1 ) and In 2 S 3 (4.73mol g -1 h -1 ).This indicated the synergistic effect between In 2 S 3 and NH 2 -MIL-68(In).As shown in Table S1, this activity was comparable to that of the reported MOFbased materials in photocatalytic reduction.More importantly, it is better than that of some typical photocatalysts, including commercial P25, g-C 3 N 4 , CdS, and ZnO.Other potential reduction products such as HCOOH, CH 3 OH, and CH 4 were not detected by 1 H NMR (Figure S3) and GC. Almost no CO was produced in the control experiment under an argon atmosphere, indicating that CO 2 rather than the catalyst or solvent was the carbon source for CO (Figure 2c, column 5).Besides, no obvious CO could be detected while the reaction was performed without light irradiation or a photocatalyst, demonstrating that it was a photoinduced reaction (Figure 2c, columns 2 and 4).Remarkably, the photocatalytic performance dropped sharply in the absence of 2c, column 3). 40,43MS(In)-7 was used for consecutive four runs without a significant loss of activity, indicating excellent reusability and stability (Figure 2b). 3.3.Mechanism of Photocatalytic Enhancement.To elucidate the reasons for the excellent photocatalytic CO 2 reduction over SMS(In)-7, the adsorption capacity of CO 2 was first investigated.As shown in Figure 2d, with a high surface area and the interaction of CO 2 with the polar group -NH 2 , the maximum CO 2 uptake for NH 2 -MIL-68(In) was 1.97 mmol g -1 (1 atm, 288 K), much larger than that for SMS(In). 44,45Notably, the high CO 2 uptake capacities were preserved over SMS(In) with a shorter sulfuration time to some extent.The CO 2 uptake capacities of SMS(In)-7 (0.203 mmol g -1) showed 2.3 times increase compared with SMS(In)-24 (pure In 2 S 3 , 0.089 mmol g -1 ) particles, benefiting from the partial preservation of the precursor NH 2 -MIL-68(In).This can be explained by the existence of -NH 2 group as Lewis basic sites that are evenly distributed on the framework of MOF, which can anchor the acidic CO 2 molecules. 46,47These larger CO 2 uptake capacities helped to promote the adsorption and enrichment of CO 2 during the photocatalysis, resulting in improved activities compared with that of In 2 S 3 (SMS(In)-24). Besides, the steady-state PL spectra were also recorded to further investigate the photocatalytic properties.The high PL intensity of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) (Figure 3a) indicated the strong recombination of photoinduced e -/h , which could explain the relatively low photocatalytic activity despite of the high adsorption capacity of CO 2 .The PL intensity of SMS(In)-7 was weaker than those of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 (pure In 2 S 3 ), suggesting the effective separation of photogenerated charges by the heterojunction construction between NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and In 2 S 3 . 38,48,49,58More available photoinduced carriers are expected to join the photoreduction of CO 2 . With the small difference between the PL intensities of SMS(In)-7 and SMS(In)-24 (In 2 S 3 ), TRPL spectroscopy was used to further compare the recombination of the photogenerated e -and h between them.As shown in Figure 3b, the PL decay profiles could be fitted by the biexponential decay equation, indicating the two radiative decay pathways; in other words, there were two recombination pathways of photocarriers in the composite material. 50The short lifetime may be related to the free-exciton PL emission, while the long lifetime may be relevant to the trap-exciton PL emission in surface defect states. 5152253 The emission lifetimes of all single components and the average lifetimes of SMS(In)-7 were shorter than the corresponding lifetimes of SMS(In)-24 (pure In 2 S 3 ).The above results suggested that the formation of homologous heterojunction benefited the electron transfer, consequently, more photoinduced electrons can interact with substance adsorbed in the surface of materials. Additionally, the flat bands of the samples measured by the Mott-Schottky plots are exhibited in Figure 3c,d.We can see that both NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 are n-type semiconductors with positive slopes. 54The derived flat-band potentials of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 were -0.6 and -0.63 eV vs Ag/AgCl (-0.40 and -0.43 eV vs NHE, pH 7), respectively, indicating their appropriate redox potentials for CO 2 photoreduction reaction. 43The conduction band (CB) of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 was estimated to be -0.60 and -0.63 eV vs NHE (pH 7), respectively. 55On the basis of the above discussion, the valence bands of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 were estimated to be 1.68 and 1.02 eV. 56herefore, the integration of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) and SMS(In)-24 could form an effective homologous type II heterojunction, which was widely used in photocatalysis to afford an improvement of the utilization of photogenerated electrons and holes.The photocatalytic mechanism is proposed in Scheme 1, where the electrons in the valence band (VB 1.02eV) were initially excited and migrated to the conduction band (CB -0.63eV) in In 2 S 3 .Supported by potential difference, the electrons in the conduction band (CB) of In 2 S 3 subsequently transferred to the conduction band (CB -0.60 eV) of NH 2 -MIL-68(In).Then, Co II (bpy) 3 2 (E(Co(bpy) 3 2/ ) -0.526eV vs NHE, pH 7, Figure S5) accepted the excited electrons from NH 2 -MIL-68(In) to generate Co I (bpy) 3 , and it preferentially reacted with CO 2 to form the intermediate Co I (bpy) 3 (CO 2 ) . 49,58The cobalt-(I) provided two electrons to CO 2 , and a six-coordinated structure of LCo III (bpy) 3 (CO 2 2-) (L TEOA or CH 3 CN) at a stable low-spin d6 configuration was formed with either TEOA or CH 3 CN. 57Afterward, such species were protonated and further reduced to afford CO, H 2 O, and the original Co(II) species.

catalyst.source: In summary, In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In)In 2 S 3 (SMS(In)) sandwich homologous heterojunction with a hollow nanotube structure was designed and assembled by the controllable in situ sulfuration of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) for visible-light-driven CO 2 reduction.
catalyst.context: In summary, In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In)In 2 S 3 (SMS(In)) sandwich homologous heterojunction with a hollow nanotube structure was designed and assembled by the controllable in situ sulfuration of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) for visible-light-driven CO 2 reduction.The subtle design not only maintained the original merits of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) but also endowed the composite material with dual interfacial homologous heterojunction shells, which showed enhanced adsorption and mass transfer of CO 2 , abundant reactive sites, and remarkably enhanced the separation and transfer efficiency of the photoinduced charge.As a consequence, the optimum sample (SMS(In)-7) exhibited outstanding photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction with a much more excellent CO generation rate (11.23 mol g -1 h -1 ), almost 3 times that of the pure MOFderived In 2 S 3 .This work proposes an instructive pathway for constructing an atomic MOF heterojunction for artificial photosynthesis. light source.context: 2.2.2.Synthesis of In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In)In 2 S 3 .In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In)In 2 S 3 was synthesized using NH 2 -MIL-68(In) as a precursor.Briefly, 0.1 g of NH 2 -MIL-68(In) obtained in the previous step and 0.2 g of thiourea were mixed uniformly in 15 mL of anhydrous ethanol and the solution was added into a Teflon-lined autoclave (25 mL) and retained at 180 C for a certain time (2, 7, 9, 12, and 24 h).The solution was then cooled to room temperature and the obtained solid was collected through centrifugation and immersed in anhydrous ethanol at 60 C for 48 h and dried at 60 C.All of the In 2 S 3 NH 2 -MIL-68(In)In 2 S 3 heterostructures were synthesized and defined as SMS(In)-X (X 2, 7, 12, and 24, which represented the sulfuration times of 2, 7, 9, 12, and 24 h, respectively). 2.3.Characterization.The X-ray diffraction pattern was recorded on PANalytical X'Pert Powder with a Cu K radiation ( 0.15406 nm) at a voltage of 40 kV and current of 40 mA.Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was performed with Bruker VERTEX 70.The morphologies and elemental composition were characterized by a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, HITACHI UHR FESEM SU8200) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, PHILIPS TECNAI 10), respectively.CO 2 adsorption isotherms were collected on Micromeritics ASAP 2020.The products were degassed under vacuum conditions at 150 C for 6 h before measuring the CO 2 adsorption at 298 K. UV-vis diffused reflectance spectra (DRS) was measured by a UV-vis spectrophotometer (U-3900, HITACHI, Japan).The steadystate and transient fluorescence was carried out by a fluorescence spectrometer (FLS 980, Edinburgh, England) coupled with a time-correlated single photocounting system.The Mott-Schottky curves were obtained on an electrochemical workstation (CHI660D) with a three-electrode cell with Pt as a counter electrode, Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode, and an electrolyte (0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution at pH 7).A Scion 456 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) using a methanizer and a GC9790 Plus gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a TCD were utilized to analyze the gas products. 2.4.Photoreduction Procedure.The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction was evaluated in an airtight glass reactor with a quartz top cap and a gas sampling port.Typically, 10 mg of photocatalyst, 45 mg of bipyridine (bpy), 60 L of CoCl 2 aqueous solution (54.6 mM), and 6 mL of the mixed reaction solution (V CH 3 CN /V TEOA 4:1) were mixed in a reactor.Then, the reactor was evacuated, and was purged with high purity CO 2 at a partial pressure of 0.1 MPa.This process was carried out several times to ensure that the reactor was full of pure CO 2 .The solution was irradiated with a 300 W xenon lamp (420 nm) with 400 mW cm -2 of light intensity (10.5 cm distance from the reaction solution).During irradiation, the reaction system was stirred and kept at a temperature of 15 C with a condenser circulation pump.The generated products were quantified every 2 h by a flame ionization detector (FID).
